captions.text:
Suppose you're stuck on a desert island with
no internet, no books, and an evil genius

who will only let you off if you can tell
him how much a million dollars weighs. Luckily,

you're a physicist, so you can weigh a million
dollars with your mind!

Here's how it goes: we approximate. We don't
know how much a dollar weighs, but we do know

how big it is… more or less. A dollar is
about 15 cm long and 5 cm wide… now how

thick is it? We don't know that either, but
money is made out of paper, and we do know

that those 'Harry Potter' books were around
800 pages long, or 400 sheets of paper. And

I think they were about 5 cm thick… so that
gives 80 sheets per cm.

Now we can find the volume of a dollar: 15
cm long times 5cm wide times one 80th of a

We still don't know how much paper weighs,
though. But we do know that a cubic centimeter

of water weighs a gram. And money's a liquid
asset, right? So we'll say a cubic centimeter

of dollars weighs a gram. Multiply 0.9 by
a million and we're done! A million dollars
weighs 900 kilograms, or two thousand pounds.

So why are approximations important in physics?
Well, you don't want to attempt a two-month

calculation without a ballpark estimate of
what you're calculating. And sometimes approximations

like ours can be pretty accurate: case in
point, according to the US treasury, a million
dollars is a ton of money. Literally.

title: Weigh a million dollars with your mind

comments.text:
Well, I'm assuming that you're quite young, judging by your profile 
picture.  I will also assume that you are confusing the two different 
tons... and the entire concept of the metric/imperial system.
1Kg ~= 2.1lb
and 1 tonne ~= 1000Kg
So 1 tonne = 2100lb
Except that 1 ton = 2000lb
or ~= 960Kg
Hope that cleared it up.
*(Or, you're just trolling.  Which is equally likely.)*

comments.text:
Every US note no matter the denomination weighs 1 gram. 1 million $1 bills 
would weigh a million grams or 1,000 kg. There are 2.204 lbs in a kg so 
that would be 2,204 lbs which is more than a ton. Q.E.D.! Factoring in 
accumulated dust and dirt would put it even more than that. Much faster way 
to do it in your head and accurate to the pound. ﻿

My labmate and I had a dispute about how much a dollar bill weighs. I said 
more, she said less, and I happened to have seven single dollar bills on me 
so we massed them on a mg balance (0.0001 g   + /- 0.2 g) and came up with 
almost exactly a gram.

comments.text:
If you are Canadian, there are additional challenges. We do not have dollar 
bills; we have dollar coins. I will now go on Google, and I will have found 
out that currently, the dollar coin is made of mostly steel, with brass 
plating, and now I have to look at a periodic table to figure out the 
atomic masses of these (in addition to finding out what brass is actually 
made of). Once again, I had to go on Google to find this information, so if 
I were stuck on a desert island, I would be screwed. I can't really find an 
analogy that works, since the only metals less dense than water are lithium 
and beryllium (I had to use a periodic table to see that), and using those 
to make coins is not a very good idea in the slightest.﻿

comments.text:
+Batuhan GENÇ The differences between a light switch and a magnetic field 
is what makes it happens. 

E = mc^2. If you change the magnetic alignment you'll change E, which means 
that either m or c has to change as well. Otherwise you break Einstein's 
theory of general relativity or the second law of thermal dynamics. The 
speed of light is a constant so it has to be the mass.
